clinicalDescription: Overview: DVT, a blood clot (thrombus) in a deep vein, usually in the legs. Can have upper extremity DVT. Presentation: Leg pain or swelling may occur in the affected leg, but there may be no symptoms. Throbbing or cramping pain in calf or thigh, swelling, red, warm skin around the painful area, swollen veins that are hard or sore to touch. upper extremity = neck, shoulder pain, swelling Assessment: physical exam, ultrasound (where there is a clot), D-dimer (elevated), venography, CT or MRI Plan: anti-couagulants, Xa inhibitors, serious then clot buster (catheter-directed thrombolysis); filters, compression stockings Prognosis: Serious, as can loosen and lodge in the lungs (pulmonary embolism) can be life-threatening.
